item.title: A 19th-century hypothesis confirmed at last https://t.co/CVw2k6wCCi
Vladimir Putin’s gamble is that he can wear down Ukraine’s army before Russia runs out of money. Some think that Russian insolvency will come first https://t.co/J6kIsYPshF

During the Senate hearings Ketanji Brown Jackson showed patience and command—traits she may need to draw upon as one of three liberal justices on a court with six conservatives https://t.co/OrzMDpD933
Emmanuel Macron looks likely to win re-election. Our model still finds him the favourite https://t.co/xtAmK0gr2X
The ejection of spooks on this scale is unprecedented: more than 400 Russian officials have been expelled from America and Europe since the war began https://t.co/xqa075466C

“We have let Vladimir Putin get away with this aggression several times before. We can’t let him get away with it again now,” urges Estonia’s prime minister. “Were that to happen, his appetite would only grow” https://t.co/dfkTdcF1Gk
Ketanji Brown Jackson is the first black woman to serve on the Supreme Court https://t.co/1QB6l8Y8El
More and more leaders are seeking power by sowing fear. They do it because it works https://t.co/9msen37xsw
Ketanji Brown Jackson, President Joe Biden’s pick to succeed Justice Stephen Breyer, is on the brink of narrowly gaining Senate confirmation https://t.co/PTD7ocf9UL

Liberal centrists around the world should see Emmanuel Macron as a cautionary tale: one person alone cannot sustain the radical centre. Our cover explains why he still gets our vote, but with reservations https://t.co/AbrlQYRcOo https://t.co/8Uo8XaXPnY
This is a good time for Ukraine to press its counter-attack: on every day during the final week of March, it gained more territory than it lost https://t.co/U107sZPQbe
Why the French election matters, and why Emmanuel Macron is still the best option for France. Our cover story this week, in ⁦@TheEconomist⁩ https://t.co/QZchC55h0G

My piece on mass expulsion of over 400 Russian diplomats from Europe in recent days. It means that roughly half of undeclared Russian intelligence officers in legal rezidenturas (stations) in Europe are being kicked out. A big blow to SVR, GRU & FSB. https://t.co/habD9GcNkb
The Taliban are pushing females out of public life https://t.co/jhtpi1afR5

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.”
The Economist’s editor-in-chief, @zannymb, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Read more here: https://t.co/vNQISgFNho https://t.co/HLDL6wKUn1

“They made us take our clothes off, lie face down, and then they searched our telephones and bodies for symbols and tattoos.” A survivor of a summary execution in Bucha tells us what happened https://t.co/LnSNus25pO
There is already so much evidence of torture, rape and murder that Russian forces should be indicted. Unfortunately, as the war drags still more evidence will come to light https://t.co/SEeyqdLYCx

STARStreak missiles, and MANPADS more generally, could help Ukrainian forces to neutralise Russian airpower without the need for new jets or direct intervention by other states https://t.co/NG5zs61Vyo

“We are witnessing a long-planned campaign by the Kremlin to exert control over neighbouring countries by brute force, no matter the human cost,” writes Estonia’s prime minister. She urges the world to “act now” https://t.co/EMCqIA5xrL
Catherine the Great of Russia’s decision to get both herself and her son inoculated against smallpox showed the power of leadership by example https://t.co/ydssRTVLq4
Man-portable air defence systems (MANPADS) are playing an unexpectedly important role in the war in Ukraine https://t.co/rIsKZXp6WL
As Russian troops retreated over the border to Belarus and Russia, pursued by Ukrainians, Kyiv began returning to normal. But although the battle is won, the war is not https://t.co/QVvIAvNJU5

In my piece for @TheEconomist, I argue that although the Soviet Union collapsed, its imperialist ideology never did.
To stop the Kremlin's war machine once and for all, we must act now.
Read the full piece, but here's a short recap how we can do it. https://t.co/kNmn859vyk

The Economist’s editor-in-chief, Zanny Minton Beddoes, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
In a wide-ranging interview, the Ukrainian president discussed the state of the war and why Putin must be defeated https://t.co/yqANwLCQyH
“Ukraine is not a battlefield; it's a crime scene,” argues @kajakallas. In a guest essay, she urges the world to “act now” https://t.co/TMnQoNzyUb
The world’s first malaria vaccine will be rolled out later this year. What other scientific tools could help defeat the mosquito-borne killer? Listen to “Babbage” https://t.co/SjK8vF6LlF

We were able to verify reports of what appears to be a summary execution in Bucha, where nine bodies lay at the side of a builder’s yard that had been used as a Russian base. A survivor tells us what happened https://t.co/TD7Zd5n3jt

When compared with the world as a whole, or even rich countries in particular, Russia’s decline over the last decade looks even worse.
Read more about the country's slide 👇
The official number of deaths from covid-19 is now 6.2m. But our model is 95% confident the true value lies between 14.2m and 24.3m excess deaths https://t.co/on8CRQvTL2
Proceedings have begun in several international courts to bring the perpetrators to justice. Two have made initial rulings in Ukraine’s favour https://t.co/1ozSsF9sml

“I will stay with these people until the end.”
The Economist’s editor-in-chief, @zannymb, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky.
Read more here: https://t.co/vNQISgXoFY https://t.co/e1cmAYsHbs
If Vladimir Putin remains in power, or even if he resigns but continues to be protected by successors, international justice will not be seen to be done https://t.co/TJO0xnw0vT
For modern autocrats, lying is more useful than killing https://t.co/iqoThdll0p
If negotiations failed, Russia could garrison troops in Donbas for years. Yet if Russia held the territory without a deal, it would find itself locked in a protracted struggle https://t.co/dBui3adhNQ
Although the official number of deaths caused by covid-19 is now 6.2m, our single best estimate is that the actual toll is 20.5m people https://t.co/9D1THmVvAL
The evidence from the battlefield confirms that Russians have committed at least three types of criminal offence in war https://t.co/fmhgtJB6mN
The presence of foreign judges on Hong Kong’s courts make them better than they would otherwise be. It also makes them seem better than they actually are https://t.co/4G5PIN8jua
A new book describes how for most modern autocrats, lying matters more than killing https://t.co/Ix8uoTKfTF

“We believe in victory. It’s impossible to believe in anything else.” Ukraine’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, speaks to The Economist’s editor-in-chief @zannymb and Russia editor @arkadyostrovsky, on a special episode of “The Economist Asks” podcast https://t.co/XpLcYzXJ1I
We speak to a survivor of a summary execution in Bucha. He and other men were beaten, tortured and ordered to be killed by Russian soldiers https://t.co/7f55TbXm38
Vladimir Putin thought Ukraine would fold after he invaded. But history shows its people come together in adversity https://t.co/5mWAopwpIt

Ukraine’s president and Poland’s prime minister have called it “genocide”. Joe Biden, America’s president, said what had happened in Bucha was a war crime and that Vladimir Putin, Russia’s president, should face an international tribunal for it https://t.co/x4ehsRVrsa

“They made us take our clothes off, lie face down, and then they searched our telephones and bodies for symbols and tattoos.” A survivor of a summary execution in Bucha tells us what happened https://t.co/2hcnJY9TEJ
“He wasn’t in the army or anything,” says a friend of one of the victims, fighting back tears. “His only crime was not immediately accepting Russky mir [Russian World].” https://t.co/UZEyBMjdkm
The West has presented a united front against the invasion of Ukraine. But many people live in countries sympathetic to Russia

“I will stay with these people until the end.”
The Economist’s editor-in-chief, @zannymb, travelled to the heart of the Ukrainian war effort to interview Volodymyr Zelensky https://t.co/2T355r2VSr
The reported toll is akin to the toughest days of the second world war https://t.co/LgO5uivUA4
Vladimir Putin’s war in Ukraine has met widespread condemnation in the West. But for now, by no means does everyone regard him, and his country, as pariahs https://t.co/2RQArbJrKS
Ukrainians are eavesdropping on the invaders and broadcasting on their frequencies https://t.co/WCtH1I0doD
About 30% of the global population live in countries whose governments are classed by the Economist Intelligence Unit as leaning towards Russia https://t.co/IZmBR530Hf
